summary: This is an email from Professor Cassell dated March 8, 2019, discussing the Office of Professional Responsibility's (OPR) investigation into the Jeffrey Epstein case. It references his 2010 request for an investigation, OPR's initial 2011 declination, and the subsequent opening of an OPR investigation in early 2019. The email is intended to share correspondence and request that victims be kept informed.

persons.name: Professor Cassell
persons.context: Author of the email. He is a professor admitted to the Utah State Bar who, in 2010, requested a U.S. Attorney to investigate the Epstein case and is now corresponding about the OPR investigation in 2019.

persons.name: Ferrer
persons.context: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida. Professor Cassell sent a letter to him on December 10, 2010, requesting an investigation into the Epstein case.

connections.description: Professor Cassell sent a formal request for investigation to U.S. Attorney Ferrer in 2010.

events.title: Cassell's Investigation Request to SD Fla.
events.description: Professor Cassell sent a letter to U.S. Attorney Ferrer (S.D. Fla.) requesting an investigation into what he called the 'most suspicious criminal case I have ever encountered.'

events.title: OPR Declines Initial Investigation
events.description: The Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) declined to investigate the Epstein case, citing ongoing litigation as the reason.

events.title: OPR Opens Investigation
events.description: The Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) opened an investigation into the Epstein case, approximately eight years after initially declining.

events.title: Cassell's Follow-up Letter to OPR
events.description: Professor Cassell sent a letter to OPR requesting that victims be kept informed about the newly opened investigation.

locations: Main Justice (likely referring to the U.S. Department of Justice headquarters in Washington, D.C.)
keyFacts: In December 2010, Professor Cassell formally requested the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida to investigate the Epstein case, which he described as the 'most suspicious criminal case' he had ever encountered.
The Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) initially declined to investigate in May 2011, citing ongoing litigation.
OPR finally opened an investigation into the case in approximately January 2019, prompting renewed correspondence from Professor Cassell.
Privileged correspondence exists between OPR and the Southern District of Florida regarding Cassell's 2010 letter, but it has not been publicly disclosed.
The email indicates plans for a conference call regarding the OPR investigation, intended to include the victims (referred to as Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2).
